answers.answer: HiWelcome to the forum!There are many reasons for a foul taste in mouth such as medications, infection of gums or cavities in teeth, post nasal drip as in sinusitis, salivary glands infection, pharyngitis or strep infection, dentures and artificial tooth or filling of dental cavities, Sjogren’s syndrome and copper or lead toxicity, poor oral hygiene, diabetes, liver problems, vitamin B12 deficiency, and over consumption of fluoride which is commonly present in certain mouthwashes and toothpastes , certain vitamins (Tri-Vi-Flor, Poly-Vi-Flor, Vi-Daylin F) , fluoridated water & sodium fluoride liquid and tablets.OK here are a few tips for you. Try them. They may help. Have citrus juices, lemonade and foods marinated in vinegar. They help in washing away the taste by producing more saliva. Brush your teeth and your tongue with a tongue cleaner at least twice in a day and surely at bedtime. Vit C tablets, over the counter oral mouthwashes will help fight the taste. Increase fibers in the diet. Eat fresh things like apples that are crunchy or rough things like popcorn scrapes the white debris off the tongue.I can understand your frustration as you are not able to reach a diagnosis. Discuss these possibilities with your doctor. Take a second opinion if you can. A comprehensive investigation is required keeping all the points in mind.Hope this helps. Please let me know if there is any thing else and do keep me posted. Take care!

question: I have had a foul tasting mouth 24/7 for the last 10 months.  I have also lost 30 pounds without trying.  I need to talk to people who have the same mouth problem.  I need reassuring I am not crazy as all the docs I've seen, and dentists ,have not helped me.  I have Parkinson's Disease, and even though I can't smell because of PD, I am assured the bad mouth is not from the PD.  How can I link up with other patients so I can compare cases via email or telephone?Ann
